captions.text: (Tommy) We're going to have a little driving lesson!
(music transition)
(Tommy) Well, I figured now would be a good time to learn to drive because I've gone for my whole life so far without having this skill so.
(Tad) We found some cones here at the radio station parking lot. So we just set those up. (Tommy) Whoopsy!
(Tad) And we're going to teach young Danicka here how to drive.
You should never have to guide your driver to the driver's seat.
(Tad) We're going to start with some pedal work. You want to have the clutch in. (Tommy) Clutch all the way in!

(Tommy) Break on two? (Tad) Do you know where first is? 
 (Tommy) I do know where first is. Up here, right?
(Tad) And then we're gonna take to this course here and see if he can weave in and out of the cones.
We're going to push in -- I usually show this with my hands where you're letting the clutch out a little bit, and you're kinda doing a nice

balance thing. You're going to feel the vehicle.
 (Tommy) Should I check my mirrors or anything?

(Tad) Then he should be road ready from there. 
 (Tommy) Off on the clutch. On on the gas. All set? (Tad) All set. 
 (Tommy) Here we go.

(Tommy) Nice and easy, my friend. Here we go.
 (Tad) Hey, hey. Alright, to the right, to the right!
(Tommy) Oh, Jesus. (Tad) Okay, let it off a little bit more. You got it going. Okay. No, no, no! (both laugh)
(Tommy) What are doing?! Jesus, panicky. (Tad) I can't believe it's still running.

(Tommy) Tad gets a little panicky. I mean I understand that. 
 (Tad) Ah, yeah! I think I was a little panicky, you know. I did have a blind driver.

(Tad) You're going straight for a cone. (Tommy) Straight? 
 (Tad) You're still going for it. Left, left, left, left! (both laugh)
(Tommy) I like the power of it. That's the thing I liked the best about driving that you guys get to do all the time. You just push your foot down and "vroom". You know, it's fantastic.

And you're moving fast. It's great! (Tad) We're doing a little cone work right now. 
 (Tommy) We're doing cone work?! (laughs)
(Tad) All the way to left. Let's see if we can do the cones. Alright, now straighten it out. Straighten it out to the right. (Tommy) Oh, no! Oh boy! (Tad)Take a right! Take a right!
(Tad) You're going to take a hard right to get through that other cone. (Tommy) Oh. boy. (Tad) Excellent.

(Tommy) Are we through her? 
 (Tad) Yep. And to the left. (Tommy) Yeah!

(Tommy) Could I imagine doing it loaded. 
 Why? Do you want to try?
(Bumper music)
(Tad) When I bought this car, there were several things that they told me that you shouldn't do with a BMW.
You shouldn't put less than 93 octane in there. You shouldn't carry jumper cables. You don't want to give anybody a jump start.
And the most important thing is, never let a blind man drive it.

title: How A Blind Person Drives A Car

comments.author: Matt K

comments.author: Valentin Paste

comments.text:
Is it true that before you'd ride with a drunk, you'd insist on driving

comments.author: carultch

comments.text:
I've taught many people how to drive manual transmission, all of them 
sighted and most of them knew how to drive an automatic and I can easily 
say that I haven't seen anyone take off as easily as you did the first 
time. I'm assuming this video wasn't edited, but if that was your first 
attempt at driving a stick then your technique was perfect. You didn't 
stall, you didn't jerk the car forward. I am very impressed. I also want to 
thank you for making these videos. I've thoroughly enjoyed watching them 
and I find it very interesting to try and understand how you perceive your 
world without sight. One thing I've always noticed though....blind people 
are always the most cheerful people you will ever meet. It's contagious! I 
love it! Keep up the good work Tommy! ﻿
comments.author: BugSmasher

comments.text: He drives better than some people I've seen on the road﻿

comments.author: Kevin Garcia

comments.text:
Back in season year 2008, MythBusters has confirmed that a blind person can 
drive a car safely by following instructions given by a passenger. It's 
also confirmed that if the sighted passenger giving instructions is drunk, 
the blind driver will drive as if he's drunk as well.﻿

comments.author: Nick Allred

comments.text:
It has its benefits. Especially in foreign countries where manual 
transmission tend to be most common. In America, you're more than likely to 
be in a minority of few that actively drive both types of vehicles, which 
means you have you're own built-in anti-theft system depending on where you 
live. Also great with gas. Personally, all of the above are nice perks, but 
I like to imagine I am driving a wonder machine, doing a series of 
operative controlling to do simple thing as just moving. :P

comments.text:
You proved nothing wrong. Again, I shall say, that my comment had *NOTHING* 
to do with him; it had to do with *anyone* learning to drive a car. You 
keep on bringing this conversation back to him, but I was merely saying 
that it is better to learn on a manual. Regardless of his being blind, and 
not actually driving anywhere; I still believe it would be better for him 
to learn on a manual.

many of my friends to drive stick in less than 10 minutes. Granted they 
weren't exactly experts at it, but they had the basic motions down; enough 
that they'd be able to operate a manual if they needed to.

explained myself. I made a general statement for *anyone* learning to 
drive. I'm not sure if you've looked at the real world lately, but last 
time I checked, blind people do not make up the majority. One learns to 
drive with ones other senses as well, not just vision.

comments.author: Glupe Meno

comments.text:
Hell yes... if you can drive a manual, you can easily drive an automatic. I 
learned on a manual, and the only trouble I have is that sometimes when I 
drive an automatic, I reach for the clutch or the gearshift, then catch 
myself. Besides that, a manual is better to learn on because you can *feel* 
the car better, you can feel the acceleration and the engine, and it's just 
a much better learning experience. ^_^
